verses.text: King Hiram of Tyre sent messengers to David, along with cedar wood, masons, and carpenters, to build a house for him.
verses.comment: The phrase 'house for him' refers to a palace for David. The text uses 'house' (Hebrew: bayit), accurately rendered.

verses.text: David realized that the LORD had established him as king over Israel, for his kingdom was highly exalted for the sake of His people Israel.
verses.comment: Faithfully follows Hebrew 'lifted up his kingdom'; 'for the sake of His people' is accurate.

verses.text: David took more wives in Jerusalem, and David fathered more sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Accurately reflects the original. 'Took more wives' mirrors Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: These are the names of the children born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
verses.comment: A straightforward list; names match Hebrew order.
Name spellings standardized to usual English forms.
Names are in the same order as Hebrew text.
'Beeliada' is a variant of 'Eliada' in parallel texts. Name retained as in Chronicles.

verses.text: When the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over all Israel, all the Philistines went up to search for David. But David heard about it and went out against them.
verses.comment: 'Went up' is the common Hebrew idiom for going into action; 'went out against them' follows the Hebrew closely.

verses.text: Now the Philistines had come and made a raid in the Valley of Rephaim.
verses.comment: 'Valley of Rephaim' is retained as the geographical term.

verses.text: David asked God, 'Shall I go up against the Philistines? Will you give them into my hand?' The LORD said to him, 'Go up, for I will give them into your hand.'
verses.comment: 'Asked God' represents Hebrew 'inquired of God.' The exchange closely reflects the original conversation.

verses.text: So they went up to Baal-perazim, and David struck them there. David said, 'God has broken through my enemies by my hand, like a breaking flood.' Therefore they called the name of that place Baal-perazim.
verses.comment: 'Like a breaking flood' translates the Hebrew image exactly.

verses.text: They left their gods there, and David gave command, and they were burned with fire.
verses.comment: 'Burned with fire' follows the law about idols.

verses.text: The Philistines made yet another raid in the valley.
verses.comment: 'Again' or 'yet another' reflects repeated action; valley context is clear from previous.

verses.text: And David again inquired of God, and God said to him, 'You shall not go up after them. Circle around them, and come against them opposite the balsam trees.'
verses.comment: 'Balsam trees' translates Hebrew 'baka trees.' Command structure follows the original order.

verses.text: When you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, then go out to battle, for God will have gone out before you to strike the army of the Philistines.'
verses.comment: 'Sound of marching' is literal; 'God will have gone out before you' is faithful.

verses.text: David did just as God commanded him, and they struck down the army of the Philistines from Gibeon to Gezer.
verses.comment: Geographical names kept as in Hebrew; 'struck down' is literal.

verses.text: And the fame of David went out into all the lands, and the LORD put the dread of him upon all the nations.
verses.comment: 'Dread of him' is literal for Hebrew 'fear of him.' Statement reflects the outcome of God's intervention.
